full_title_en: Rome III Diagnostic Criteria for Irritable Bowel Syndrome (IBS)
medium_description_en: Official Rome III criteria for the diagnosis of irritable bowel syndrome.
instructions_en: Recurrent abdominal pain or discomfort, 3 days per month in the last 3 months (12 weeks), associated with ≥2 of the criteria below. The criteria are fulfilled with symptoms onset 6 months prior to diagnosis.

seo.meta_description_en: The Rome III Diagnostic Criteria provides criteria for diagnosis of irritable bowel syndrome (IBS) within 12 week period, updated from the Rome II.
seo.keywords_en: rome iii, Rome 3, Rome diagnostic, Rome diagnosis, Rome ibs, Rome irritable, Rome bowel, Rome diarrhea, ibs diagnosis, ibs dx

how_to_use.pearls_pitfalls_en:
• The Rome III criteria help diagnose irritable bowel syndrome (IBS).

Points to keep in mind:

  • There remains no objective reference (i.e. ‘gold’) standard for IBS; the criteria were developed through a literature review and consensus process.
how_to_use.why_use_en: The symptoms that define IBS are subjective and self-reported, making a classification system helpful. Moreover, there is evidence to support the notion that patients who meet formal Rome criteria may be more likely to respond to certain therapies.

next_steps.advice_en: The Rome III criteria are helpful in classifying patients and for determining potential therapies.
next_steps.management_en: We are unaware of validated management algorithms using the Rome criteria.
next_steps.critical_actions_en: IBS is a ‘rule-out’ diagnosis, which is to say all other possibilities must be ruled out first.

about.formula_en:
Recurrent abdominal pain or discomfort, 3 days per month in the last 3 months, associated with two or more of the criteria below:

  • Criteria fulfilled for the last 3 months with symptom onset 6 months prior to diagnosis.
  • Criteria:
    1. Improvement with defecation; and/or
    2. Onset associated with a change in stool frequency; and/or
    3. Onset associated with a change in stool form (appearance).

Original/Primary Reference.text: Drossman DA. The functional gastrointestinal disorders and the Rome II process. Gut. 1999;45(suppl II):II1–II5.

creator_info.about_en: Douglas Drossman, MD, is professor emeritus of medicine and psychiatry at the University of North Carolina School of Medicine. He is founder, President Emeritus and Chief of Operations of the Rome Foundation. He is also the founder of the Drossman Center for the Education and Practice of Biopsychosocial Care and Drossman Consulting, LLC. Dr. Drossman has written over 500 articles and book chapters, has published two books, a GI procedure manual and a textbook of functional GI disorders (Rome I-IV), and serves on six editorial and advisory boards.
